title: AI-Researcher: Autonomous Scientific Innovation
authors: Jiabin Tang, Lianghao Xia, Zhonghang Li, Chao Huang
keyAssumptions: Scientific innovation requires human intellectual leadership at every stage; AI systems can only assist with isolated tasks
citation: Tang, J., Xia, L., Li, Z., & Huang, C. (2025). AI-Researcher: Autonomous Scientific Innovation. arXiv preprint arXiv:2505.18705.
notes: Demonstrates autonomous orchestration of complete research pipeline from literature review to manuscript preparation. Achieves remarkable implementation success rates and human-level paper quality.

title: Robin: A multi-agent system for automating scientific discovery
authors: Ali Essam Ghareeb, Benjamin Chang, Ludovico Mitchener, Angela Yiu, Caralyn J. Szostkiewicz, Jon M. Laurent, Muhammed T. Razzak, Andrew D. White, Michaela M. Hinks, Samuel G. Rodriques
keyAssumptions: Scientific discovery stages must be handled independently; Literature synthesis and experimental design cannot be integrated
citation: Ghareeb, A. E., Chang, B., Mitchener, L., et al. (2025). Robin: A multi-agent system for automating scientific discovery. arXiv preprint arXiv:2505.13400.
notes: First multi-agent system automating all intellectual steps of scientific process. Identified novel dAMD treatment (ripasudil) through autonomous hypothesis-experiment-analysis loop.

title: The AI Scientist-v2: Workshop-Level Automated Scientific Discovery via Agentic Tree Search
authors: Yutaro Yamada, Robert Tjarko Lange, Cong Lu, Shengran Hu, Chris Lu, Jakob Foerster, Jeff Clune, David Ha
keyAssumptions: AI-generated research requires human templates; AI cannot pass peer review; Research systems need domain-specific scaffolding
citation: Yamada, Y., Lange, R. T., Lu, C., et al. (2025). The AI Scientist-v2: Workshop-Level Automated Scientific Discovery via Agentic Tree Search. arXiv preprint arXiv:2504.08066.
notes: First fully AI-generated paper to exceed human acceptance threshold in peer review. Eliminates template dependency through progressive agentic tree-search methodology.

title: ScienceBoard: Evaluating Multimodal Autonomous Agents in Realistic Scientific Workflows
authors: Qiushi Sun, Zhoumianze Liu, Chang Ma, et al.
keyAssumptions: Simple task completion metrics reflect scientific workflow performance; Current benchmarks adequately assess scientific agents
citation: Sun, Q., Liu, Z., Ma, C., et al. (2025). ScienceBoard: Evaluating Multimodal Autonomous Agents in Realistic Scientific Workflows. arXiv preprint arXiv:2505.19897.
notes: Comprehensive benchmark platform revealing gaps between agent capabilities and scientific workflow requirements. Emphasizes multimodal integration importance.

title: MLR-Bench: Evaluating AI Agents on Open-Ended Machine Learning Research
authors: Hui Chen, Miao Xiong, Yujie Lu, Wei Han, Ailin Deng, Yufei He, Jiaying Wu, Yibo Li, Yue Liu, Bryan Hooi
keyAssumptions: AI agents can reliably conduct experimental validation; Coding agents produce valid experimental results; Research evaluation can focus on final output quality
citation: Chen, H., Xiong, M., Lu, Y., et al. (2025). MLR-Bench: Evaluating AI Agents on Open-Ended Machine Learning Research. arXiv preprint arXiv:2505.19955.
notes: Reveals critical reliability crisis: 80% fabrication rate in experimental results from coding agents. Highlights major barriers to scientific reliability in AI systems.
